titlestmt.titleproper: Neighborhood Garden Association of Philadelphia collection 1953-1971
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012

did.unittitle: Neighborhood Garden Association of Philadelphia collection

bioghist.p: The Neighborhood Garden Association of Philadelphia was founded in 1953 by Louise Bush-Brown, an author of gardening books and the Director of the Pennsylvania School of Horticulture in Ambler. After a trip to Europe, she got the idea of planting window boxes in depressed areas of Philadelphia to improve conditions in the inner-city neighborhoods and organized constructive garden projects for adult and youth groups.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of materials related to the Neighborhood Garden Association of Philadelphia. Items include: a copy of the by-laws; a list of board of directors (1969); minutes (1971); correspondence of Louise Bush-Brown related to NGA lectures and programs; reports on projects and histories of the NGA; several drafts of "Flower That Touched a City's Heart," an article by Bush-Brown on the NGA; a scrapbook (1955-1966); and photo albums. The collection includes many slides documenting the association's projects, beginning in 1953. These projects include the Garden Block program and Demonstration Gardens. Many of the slides note the addresses of the gardens and the year.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
